notes.div: FREN 101x does not count toward the liberal education requirements except by permission of the departmental chair

description.div: Main emphasis on the development of comprehension of written and spoken French; reading of simple texts dealing primarily with contemporary France and French life; oral and aural drill supplemented by practice in language laboratory.

prerequisite.div: FREN 101 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

notes.div: FREN 102x does not count toward the liberal education requirements except by permission of the departmental chair.

description.div: Continuation of FREN 101.

notes.div: Open to graduate students, juniors, and seniors. Does not apply to the liberal education requirements. The sequence of FREN 181 and 281 is designd primarily to meet the needs of graduate students preparing for the French reading examination.

description.div: Rapid course in the essentials of grammar designed to prepare mature students for reading various types of literary or technical prose texts.

prerequisite.div: FREN 102 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Practice in oral and written expression and introduction to narrative texts. Grammar review and vocabulary expansion are tied to different situations of interaction.

prerequisite.div: FREN 201 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Continuation of FREN 201, with emphasis on reading comprehension. Class discussion in French based on texts.

prerequisite.div: FREN 202 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Guided practice in speaking and writing French.

prerequisite.div: FREN 203 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Continuation of FREN 203.

prerequisite.div: FREN 102 or equivalent score on French Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Covers the same material as FREN 201-202 and counts as 201-202 in satisfying the liberal education requirements of the College of Arts and Sciences.

notes.div: Permission for a student to take these courses more than once may be obtained from the instructor if the area of concentration has been changed.

description.div: Masterpieces of French literature in translation. Selected texts to be announced in the schedule and course description booklet.
Reading of masterpieces from the Middle Ages to the present.
Reading of masterpieces from the Middle Ages to the present.

course.title: Advanced Composition, Grammar, and Conversation I

description.div: Emphasis on written and oral expression. Review of difficult concepts of French grammar.

course.title: Advanced Composition, Grammar, and Conversation II

description.div: Continuation of FREN 303.

course.title: French for Business and Commerce I

description.div: Initiates a special sequence of particular interest to students of international business and international affairs. French economy, business practices and documents, business correspondence, commercial and economic vocabulary.

course.title: French for Business and Commerce II

description.div: Continuation of FREN 307.

Analysis of French sounds, meaningful contrasts, stress and intonation patterns; correction of specific mistakes in pronunciation. Phonetic transcription, studies in articulation and aural training with use of recordings and individualized exercises.

Survey of French social, cultural, and political history and of significant contributions in arts and letters through the eighteenth century. Lectures given in French are supplemented by slides and class discussion.
French 321 continued to the present.

Deals with at least two of the following non-European Francophone areas; Canada and French pockets in the US; the Caribbean; the Magreb; and Sub-Saharan Africa. Other areas such as Southeast Asia or Polynesia may be included. Examines the culture of the areas in light of social and political problems arising from colonization and independence as reflected in literature, film, popular culture, and the fine arts.
Special research project or reading program under the direction of a staff member in the department.

prerequisite.div: Open to candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the College of Arts and Sciences and to seniors and especially qualified juniors, with consent of the instructor.

description.div: Detailed analysis of French syntax giving students the means to achieve greater sophistication in self-expression.

Principles of explication of texts, translation and composition in French, review of linguistic principles, for advanced students, particularly prospective teachers, who wish to acquire a more sophisticated means of expression in French.
Principles of translation, French-English and English-French. Attention to problems of vocabulary, syntax, semantics, and technical, literary, and commercial translation.
Analysis of interrelationships of cultural, social, economic, and political factors contributing to French culture and civilization.

course.title: French Literary Treasures of the Middle Ages

description.div: French medieval short story, epic, novel, farce, satire, read in modern French. May include the Song of Roland, Lais, of Marie de France, Tristan, a romance by Chr ÃƒÆ’Ã†â€™Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â©tien de Troyes such as Ecre et Enide, the satire of Aucassin et Nicolette, the farce of Pathelin, Villon's Testament.
The plays of Corneille, Moliere, Racine.
Prose and poetry.
Philosophical writings and the theatre of eighteenth-century France.
Works of Voltaire, Rousseau, Montesquieu, Diderot. Lectures, discussion, and reports.
Readings in the major developments in narrative, drama, poetry and the essay from 1800 to 1860. Authors include Balzac, Hugo, Stendhal, Nerval and Gauthier.
Readings in the major developments in prose and verse from 1850 to 1900. Authors include Baudelaire, Mallarme, Rimbaud and Verlaine.
Main trends in the French novel from 1900 to the present.
Main trends in French poetry and theater from 1900 to the present.
Survey of literature of French Canada in its cultural context.
Survey of literature and film from French speaking African and Caribbean cultures.

course.title: Studies in Francophone Literature and Cultures

description.div: A topic, genre, author, and geographical area of the African Diaspora.
Special research project or reading program under the direction of a staff member in the department.

notes.div: Specific topic to be covered in any given semester and credit to be awarded to be determined by the instructor at that time.

description.div: Language, literature, and civilization.

prerequisite.div: Admission to masters degree program and permission of major adviser

description.div: Phonology and morphology of Old French as derived from Vulgar Latin. Attention to a detailed reading of the “Chanson de Roland” and the “Lais” of Marie de France.
Readings from Medieval epics, saints’ lives, Arthurian romances, prose chronicles, and drama. Introduction to the modern critical principles of editing Medieval manuscript.
Masterpieces of Renaissance literature. Works of Rabelais, the Pleiade, Montaigne, etc.

FREN 919 continued. Seminars in French (3 cr per sem) Under the headings listed below, the works of one author, or groups of works centering in a period, or those illustrating the development of a literary age are studied with respect to content, sources, style, and influence.
Individual research on a literary or linguistic problem involving original investigation in areas not covered by seminars or thesis.
Topic varies.

prerequisite.div: Admission to doctoral degree program and permission of supervisory committee chair
